history.content: When we provided such priority, it turned out to be ineffective.  For almost all CS upper div classes in a given semester the class either had enough capacity to accept all interested non-majors or no capacity to accept any interested non-majors.  Pursuing the minor didn't in practice help students get into particular upper div classes.  In a given semester their might be one class for which it was helpful.  Faculty (and advising staff) believed it gave a certain amount of false hope to advertise a priority that in practice was nearly useless.  We are unlikely to reconsider that decision unless conditions were to change in a direction that made that distinction likely to have more value.

children.subject: 162, 164, 170, and 188 are usually easy to get into as a minor
I think the idea is that the staff wouldn't know which class would have this capacity is until after Phase II / all the majors have signed up for classes.

Even if it only helps for one class a semester, that seems worthwhile. The minor only requires 3 upper divisions, and I'm genuinely concerned I won't be able to get into 3 upper division classes over the next 2 semesters. Having priority make a difference in at least one class would help with that a lot. Hope you all bring it back!
Is there reason to expect the distribution to be different than that of majors'?

Definitely. Popularity is for sure a big concern for minors -- more popular classes can be very difficult to get into.

Beyond that, some people majoring in CS will likely opt for classes that are heavier in theory (more truly Computer Science) than minors, who are more likely to be taking upper-divs directly useful for industry.

When you only have three classes to take that are required, intuitively it would make more sense to use them on things that you can use in interviews/engineering roles (186/188/189 + 160/161/168/169). I would bet that classes like 170/172/174/176 + 150/152/164 are less likely to be taken by minors.

Hm. It seems that you're basing your argument that CS minors are more likely to be focused on CS industry, which is the opposite of what I would expect (i.e. I would expect that CS minors are more likely to be taking some CS classes for fun, and aren't planning on doing interviews/software engineering, as opposed to a career related to what their primary major(s) are). I would be curious if there was any data on this.

And the phrasing of "using" the number of classes you are required to take "on" specific areas seems weird; it's not like you're limited as to how many classes you take, so I don't see a reason for this to matter. (At least, my model of the reason for why people pursue minors is that they take the classes they would take anyway, and identify as a minor if that happens to (almost) qualify them for the minor.)

Either way, I'll grant that there's probably some demographic differences that I hadn't considered though.

Hmm yeah interesting. IMO, I would say people interested in CS are more likely to be drawn to things like data science + app programming + fun projects.

I also was thinking about it like this: People majoring in CS/EECS are more likely to take EE classes (intuitively), as well as the more theoretical classes that lend themselves to graduate school, because CS majors are far more likely than minors to pursue that.

Finally, to address the "using" comment. It's pretty difficult to get into classes as a minor (absolutely 0 priority). Its not a stretch to say you're limited to how many classes you can take, and I also said it that way because I'm "using" slots on my schedule for CS. If I could, I would double major, but  I don't have time (Public Health being my primary), so minoring is essentially taking up slots on my schedule that I "use" for classes that I hope I enjoy/are useful.

Its also worth noting, a career in CS is definitely possible after 61A/B/C and that's it. A few decals and some self-taught stuff, and you're going to be competitive for a lot of software jobs. For minors, that's even more true, because of the upper-divs and sustained exposure throughout college.

Ah, I was specifically trying to contrast between CS minors and CS majors, and not including EECS majors at all (or including EECS majors with a CS focus, I suppose), so I wouldn't expect EE classes to be common enough for either group to be relevant. Theoretical classes, yes, but that's then going back to whether CS minors are focusing on practical classes or classes they find interesting (which could reasonably include theory classes).

I don't disagree at all that a career in CS is possible without a major; I was just noting that I expect that minors are less likely to be interested in CS careers than majors, i.e. interest in CS as a hobby (e.g. data science, coding projects) doesn't necessarily translate to interest in CS as a career.
What classes do CS minors typically take?

history.content: Will CS minors ever get priority over nonmajors for cs upper divs?
history.subject: CS Minor and CS Upper Divs
